header.title: The Importance of Supporting Community Roles

body.p: Although tools are an important part of a development environment they are not what makes a project successful. The support of a variety of important roles within a project is what really counts. Broadly speaking these roles are:

ul.li: User - someone who is trying to fill a need by adopting the outputs of a project. Directly involving the users in a project helps to ensure that it does what is intended. By providing user focussed documentation, support and bug/feature tracking users can be directly involved with the project.

Developer - someone who started life as a user, but has found the need to contribute to the project in the form of documentation, user support or code patches (in the case of a software project). Developers may also contribute by assisting with the design of solutions to bugs and implementations of feature requests.

Committer - someone who has been active as a developer for some time and has been recognised by the community as being a valuable member of the project team. They have the ability to directly contribute to the project by editing the source files for published documentation and software products.

Programme Management Committee Member - someone who is responsible for the strategic objectives of the project. The PMC steers the project on behalf of the community and attempts to ensure a unified vision is available to all.

body.p: Any set of tools adopted by a project must be adopted in order to facilitate these different roles. For example, users need access to clear and accurate documentation. Whilst a wiki may be attractive from the point of view of easy editing, is it really the best tool for your users? Perhaps you should be using a wiki for your developers, but have an editing and publishing cycle for your users docs.

Another important consideration when selecting your project's supporting tools is their ability to facilitate communication between the different project roles. In an open development community it is important that all members of the community, from user onwards, feel that they have some influence on the project. If users do not feel that they have an audible voice they will not become developers on your project. Without developers your committer base will dry up. Without committers you are unlikely to be able to form a functioning Project Management Committee.

The diagram below illustrates what tools and what resources are required by each of the roles. It should be noted that each role with increasingly responsibility subsumes the previous roles. So, a developer requires all the same tools and resources as a user, similarly a committer requires all the tools and resources of a developer and so on. Each role may use the tools in a different way. It is therefore important to consider the different tool uses when selecting from the alternatives available.

section.title: Supporting Users
section.p: Anyone who contributes to a project must first become a user, that is they must first understand what the project can and can't do, they must be able to understand what is in scope and what is not. As such the education and support of the user is the first priority in any project wishing to reach sustainability. However, there is little point in supporting users unless they are first being attracted to the project.

In order to attract users to the project it is vital that the project is able to disseminate information about itself in an efficient and meaningful way. A clear and understandable user section on the project website is clearly important here. However, it is also important to provide information for third party sites. One technique that is of considerable value is to provide data about the project in a machine readable form, such as a DOAP (Description of a Project) file.
